review.title: Anomaly detection and classification for streaming data using PDEs
review.abstract: Nondominated sorting, or Pareto Depth Analysis (PDA), is widely used in multi-objective optimization and has recently found important applications in multi-criteria anomaly detection. We propose in this paper a fast real-time streaming version of the PDA algorithm for anomaly detection and classification that exploits the computational advantages of partial differential equation (PDE) continuum limits. We prove convergence rates for the continuum approximations and present the results of numerical experiments.

sections.heading: 2.2 Anomaly detection
sections.text: To illustrate the computerized advantages of PDE-based ranking, we consider a concrete application of the non-dominated sorting to anomalous detection [20]. Anomalous detection refers to the problem of detecting patterns in data that differ from the expected behavior. It is an important and challenging problem with a wide range of applications, including computer intrusion detection, video surveillance, credit card fraud and biometrics [17, 8]. Many anomaly detection algorithms are based on the availability of a distance (or similarity) between data samples and search for anomalies by finding samples that are far away from their closest neighbors (see [20] and references therein). These algorithms are usually called similarity and are widely used due to their simplicity and robustness. In contrast, feature-based algorithms strive to embed the data in a relatively one-dimensional euclidean area and make use of others (or euclidean).

sections.heading: 4 Real-time anomaly detection
sections.text: We propose here a modification of the PDA data to determine whether Yt is an anomaly that can only be considered as a current dataset. [20] Suppose we have a stream of possibly non-stationary data [Yt], and we need to determine whether Yt is an anomaly based only on the previous history. [20] Suppose we assume that 0 ≤ ci (·, ·), it cannot be feasible to use this entire history, especially if t is large and the windowed historyHt = {Ys: s < t}. (10) We use the history Ht as training data to determine whether Yt is an anomaly.

sections.heading: 5 Numerical results
sections.text: The first two experiments were performed with synthetic data from [19, 20]. Streaming experiments consist of a total of 1500 samples with a window history of T = 500. To emphasize the adaptive nature of our algorithm, each of these experiments produces a significant trend change in the middle of the stream. The third and final experiment was performed with real footpath data from a video surveillance problem. To evaluate the performance of the streaming algorithm, we use a Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve and its resulting Area Under the Curve (AUC). We look at how the AUC varies over time as the algorithm takes points from a stream. If we change the trend in the simulated streams, we modify the data used to generate the ROC curves accordingly.

sections.heading: 5.1 Uniformly distributed data
sections.text: The first experiment carried out with synthetic data, i.e., took uniform samples [0, 1] 2 to be nominal, and uniform samples from the region [1, 1,1] 2\ [0, 1] 2 to be anomalous. Halfway through the current, the nominal region was changed to the field [0, 2] 2, and the corresponding anomalous region to [0, 2,2] 2\ [0, 2] 2. The two similarity criteria were simply taken as component-wise differences; the nearest neighbouring parameters were given as k1 = 6, k2 = 7. At each step in the simulated current, there was a 0.05 probability of pulling out of the anomalous region. Figure 3 (a) shows the resulting AUCs at any point in time. As expected, a significant drop in the AUC of the anomaly to the middle of the trend can be detected if the trend is changed.

sections.heading: 5.2 Categorical data
sections.text: For the second experiment, we used the synthetic categorical data from [20]. Each sample consists of 2 groups of categorical data A1 and A2. Each group consists of 20 different attributes, with each attribute taking a different number of values. The number of possible values for the jth attribute of the ith group, denoted ni, j, is uniformly random between 6 and 10. Each attribute is then assigned to a categorical distribution with the parameters p1,.., pni, j, which in turn are drawn from a Dirichlet distribution with the parameters α1,., αni, j. The nominal distribution is characterized by setting α1 = 5 and αk = 1 for each attribute. For the anomalous distribution, we put αk = 1 for each k.

sections.heading: 5.3 Pedestrian trajectories
sections.text: Our third experiment consisted of data from a real pedestrian trajectory dataset [25], with over 100,000 trajectories. The first similarity criterion used to compare trajectories was their difference in form given by the 2-distance between the interpolated trajectories. The second was their difference in walking speed given by the 2-distance between the velocity histograms of each trajectory.As a preliminary experiment, we tested the anomaly detection and anomaly classification on 1666 trajectories from a single day. These trajectories were manually marked as normal or anomalous by [20]. In each experiment, the training group consisted of 500 trajectories randomly drawn from a total of 1666 trajectories on that day. The mean AUCs of the PDE-based and exact sorting-based algorithms were 0.9274 ± 0.0085 ± 0.0072, and the ROC and curves are shown in 4.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have shown how some recently discovered PDE continuum boundaries for non-dominated sorting can be used to detect and classify anomalies in real time in a streaming environment, using new PDE continuum boundaries for arrangement within non-dominated layers. We have demonstrated convergence rates for continuity approximations and presented the results of numerical experiments with synthetic and real data that show that our algorithm can adapt quickly and efficiently to a changing data stream. Although we focused on the problem of anomaly detection in this paper, the ideas are not limited to this context. In fact, non-dominated sorting is often used in multi-objective optimization, and the ideas in this paper are potentially applicable to any such application, leaving many interesting problems for future work.

sections.heading: A Derivation of new continuum limits

Since there are n points in the totality, it is reasonable to suppose that each front in the order of the n 2 Pareto fronts n (0, 1), that each front in the order of the n 2 Pareto fronts. referenceMentions.context: Since there is no canonical linear ordering for multivariate data, many different notions of ordering have been proposed in the literature [23], and the problem is very much application dependent.
In the database community the Pareto-optimal solutions are called the skyline of the dataset [22].

The notion of Pareto-optimality is widely used in evolutionary algorithms for multiobjective optimization [27], such as the Nondominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm (NSGA-II) [10], the Strength Pareto Evolutionary Algorithm (SPEA) [29, 30], and the Pareto envelope-based selection algorithm (PESA) [9], among many others (see [15] for a survey).

As it turns out, nondominated sorting is equivalent to the longest chain problem, which has a long history in combinatorics and probability [2].
Due to the wide use of NSGA-II, there has been significant interest in fast algorithms for nondominated sorting [10, 21, 14].

[5] established a continuum limit for nondominated sorting that corresponds to solving a Hamilton-Jacobi partial differential equation (HJE).
[6] recently proposed a sublinear algorithm for approximate nondominated sorting called PDE-based ranking that is based on estimating the distribution of the data and solving the HJE numerically.

To illustrate this in a concrete setting, we propose a new real-time version of the multicriteria PDA anomaly detection algorithm from [20] that uses PDE-based ranking in place of nondominated sorting.

The two dimensional version of Jensen’s algorithm was discovered independently in the combinatorics community by Felsner and Wernisch [13].

However, recent numerical results have suggested a better asymptotic complexity as d → ∞ with n fixed [20].

metadata.abstractText: Nondominated sorting, or Pareto Depth Analysis (PDA), is widely used in multiobjective optimization and has recently found important applications in multi-criteria anomaly detection. We propose in this paper a fast real-time streaming version of the PDA algorithm for anomaly detection and classification that exploits the computational advantages of partial differential equation (PDE) continuum limits. We prove convergence rates for the continuum approximations and present the results of numerical experiments.
